CLUE: Advantages given to competitors to equalize chances of winning
OUTPUT: ['Equal starting resources: Providing all competitors with the same initial resources, such as money or equipment, can level the playing field and give everyone an equal chance at winning.', 'Skill-based challenges: Designing challenges that require specific skills, rather than relying on random chance, can help to create a more balanced competition', 'Blind draws: Conducting draws without revealing the contents of the prize pool or the identities of the competitors can help to prevent bias and ensure fairness.', 'Random seeding: Seeding competitors in a random order can help to prevent any one competitor from having an advantage due to their position in the bracket.', 'Time limits: Setting time limits for each challenge can help to prevent any one competitor from having too much time to prepare or strategize, giving everyone an equal chance at success.', 'Multi-stage challenges: Designing challenges that are broken down into multiple stages can help to ensure that the competition is fair and that no one competitor has an unfair advantage in any one stage.', 'Independent judging: Having independent judges or a panel of judges can help to prevent bias and ensure fairness in the evaluation of competitors.', 'Publicly available rules: Making the rules of the competition publicly available can help to prevent confusion or misunderstandings, and ensure that all competitors are held to the same standards.', 'Transparency: Being transparent about how the competition is being run and how decisions are made can help to build trust among competitors and spectators, and ensure that everyone has an equal chance at winning.', 'Providing resources for underdog competitors: Offering additional resources or support to underdog competitors can help to level the playing field and give them a better chance at winning.']
